text: my name is Paul Graziano we're sitting
in 146 24 30 second Avenue which was
formerly the house of John Bruce and his
family and my parents live right next
door he was essentially was like a
grandfather to me we were extremely
close and we had talked about the house
a lot and and and he had said you know I
want you to have the house you know my
son's don't want the house my
grandchildren don't want the house so
you're the perfect person to have it you
appreciate it more than anybody and so
after he passed away we agreed on a
price of four hundred and seven thousand
dollars which is extremely generous it's
a probably half market and not only did
I purchase the house but I essentially
purchased the entire contents of the
house much of the house had not been
touched since renovations were done in
the 50s I have restored a number of the
spaces in a number of the rooms mostly
by myself I've done about ninety percent
of the work myself I started in the
Attic January 2010 this is the front
room in the Attic had no floor and had
no walls so it's got oak flooring from a
house that was they removed their 85
year old oak floors and I salvaged the
floors and then the paneling is real
wood paneling which my father and I and
and somebody else put up the one feature
i saved from this room was the built-in
drawers which are kind of neat so the
hallway was covered in wall-to-wall
carpeting from the 50s pulled up all of
that to expose the original southern
yellow pine floors which were originally
stained dark but they when they sanded
them they brought them back to its
original color which is a very kind of
light color very beautiful the door had
seven coats of paint on it so I stripped
the doors down to the original stained
banisters not finished yet that's the
last piece that needs to be done this is
the second floor former living room then
bedroom now music room the far walls
were originally covered with again fake
paneling there was also a jerry-rigged
closet once I started pulling the
paneling off the entire wall was covered
in a frame that window was covered up
for 60 years there was an air
conditioner in the window and they
created an air-conditioning slip because
that was the modern thing to do in the
50s so as a little ridiculous this is
the groovy 1960s kitchen I have not
touched it all the hardware all of the
the oven the dishwasher they're all
vintage ah this kitchen is usable under
it's under the current regime but it
needs you know twenty-thousand-dollar
redo it's it's as I said I'm trying to
bring this house back for the period
stuff but you know I also want this to
be for comfort and this room is not
particularly comfortable this is the
basement which is a mess this is a one
of the spaces I have not dealt with yet
we see mr. Bruce's father's carpentry
shop there's a small greenhouse once I
get the main rooms taking care of the
you know the greenhouse is important to
me because I actually garden and do
planting this is actually the space
underneath the front porch my ultimate
goal is to clear all of this out and
build a shotgun recording studio in here
because it's incredibly soundproof so
far the renovations have cost under
seven thousand dollars the work that's
going to cost a lot of money will
probably come next year I'm going to be
putting dormers in the Attic a second
bathroom actually a third bathroom
there's a bath and a half in the house
today and then renovating the bathroom
on the second floor and renovating the
kitchen putting an addition onto the
back of
kitchen and opening up the porch in the
front which was closed in when it was
turned into a bedroom and in the 1960s
all of that will probably cost around a
hundred thousand dollars
